column1: #FORMAT=WebAnno TSV 3.2
#T_SP=webanno.custom.Referent|entity|infstat
#T_RL=webanno.custom.Coref|type|BT_webanno.custom.Referent
#Text=Deliver a Speech Using Visual Aids and Props
#Text=You 've been tasked with giving a speech or presentation .
#Text=The last thing you want to do is bore your audience and you know that the audience would especially want a speaker who is interesting , very informative , and can provide entertainment .
#Text=So how do you make your presentation a powerful one ?
#Text=Through the use of visual aids !
#Text=Steps
#Text=Engage your audience to capture their attention , and hold it throughout , adding power to your message .
#Text=Make the opening of your presentation a powerful one , if you want to gain control of your audience 's attention .
#Text=Since the first thirty seconds of your speech are probably the most important , you will need some passion for your subject matter here .
#Text=In that period of time you must grab the attention of the audience and engage their interest in what you have to say in your speech .
#Text=Use an icebreaker like a joke or an introduction .
#Text=However , your opening will carry much more impact if it is not only a bit off-the-wall , but also relevant to your message .
#Text=Consider opening your speech by launching a small rocket to seize attention .
#Text=Just a small rocket pumped up with an air charge or a gyro would be enough to get your point across .
#Text=It 's simple , it 's effective , and it 's straight to the point .
#Text=In the first thirty seconds , you 've grabbed their full attention .
#Text=Once your audience is interested and intrigued , move forward and advance to the core part of your speech .
#Text=The more of the five senses ( sight , hearing , taste , touch , and smell )
#Text=you can involve in that part of the speech , the better you can hold your audience 's interest .
#Text=Make use of clear illustrations or examples .

#Text=As an example , in a company presentation where the speaker was saying that the way forward was a matter , simply , of following a recipe and making sure that all of the ingredients were there .
#Text=Just prior to saying this the room was filled with the smell of hot , fresh-baked chocolate chip cookies as the caterers brought in warm plates of gooey cookies .
#Text=Her illustration was well received and her presentation continued to compare “ the way forward ” to her “ cookie recipe ” .
#Text=The message was offbeat and had a strong impact .
#Text=When using a PowerPoint presentation as visuals , be careful not to read the slides or the bullet points word-for-word as this might imply that your audience cannot read for themselves .
#Text=Rather , use the slides or bullet points as a guide to drive home the strongest parts of the message you are delivering .
#Text=Do n't read your slides to your audience .
#Text=Instead create a bond with them as a speaker , by giving your full attention and eye contact to them .
#Text=You do not have to keep looking at your slides for long periods of time through the course of your speech .
#Text=Do not underestimate the value of a good story .
#Text=Try not to speak monotonously and indifferently , which creates a sense of detachment not appreciated by the audience .
#Text=It implies a lack of passion for your subject matter and , after all , if you do n't care about the subject , why should they ?
#Text=The stage is not the time to become dispassionate .
#Text=Instead , tell your audience a really juicy and riveting story .
#Text=Use emotion to sway your listeners .
#Text=Watch and copy good speakers .
#Text=You can learn from the most prominent orators and their secrets of success by telling our audience a good story that illustrates your point .
#Text=Learn to make us of a pregnant pause .
#Text=Somerset Maugham said that “ if you take a pause , make it a long one . ”
#Text=Scientists determined that being silent ( not shouting ) serves as an attention grabber , as long as it is on purpose .
#Text=Let your silence be thoughtful and deliberate .
#Text=You will impress everyone , if after a reflecting pause , you continue your speech with more energy .
#Text=Contrasts are a great way to capture attention .
#Text=Your pauses will have the added benefit of giving you listener the ability to think about your words and really absorb your message .
#Text=Involve as many of your audience members ' five senses as possible .
#Text=Use visual aids and props , tell moving stories , vary your speech patterns , use a pregnant pause , and offer them something to taste , feel , or smell .
#Text=Get them up out of their chairs and moving .
#Text=Do whatever you can think of to get them involved !
#Text=Video
#Text=Tips

#Text=To give a presentation about the current plight of Ethiopia , as an example , your slide might state that , according to the United Nations , 126,000 children are in urgent need of food and medical assistance there .

#Text=However , instead of stating this fact , since your audience is able to read the slide for themselves , you carry on to speak about the drought and skyrocketing global food prices that are causing this problem .
